messageBody:
So your argument is that we really don't need anything other than assertTrue? I'd have to disagree.

JUnit is a TESTING FRAMEWORK. By using it, testing should be made easier. I'd like to not have to reinvent the wheel for many of these assertions. I understand that I can easily write my own assertion library in just a couple hours but why should I have to? Certainly, after years of use, we have identified many assertions that would be useful to the community at large. As they are identified, it seems natural for JUnit to provide them in future releases.

-Chris



-----Original Message-----
From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbr@...]
Sent: Friday, April 05, 2002 9:52 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] assertContains? -> junit development question?


> it would create easier-to-read and maintain tests than having to
> currently
> do containment checks by writing
>
> if(str.indexOf(keywordStr) < 0) {
> fail("failed.");
> }

Is there something wrong with:

assertTrue( str.indexOf(keywordStr) >= 0 )?

I used to want many, many custom assertions. I now believe it's cleaner simply
to build a lot of custom methods answering boolean, then using assertTrue() and
assertFalse(). What changes in your example is the condition, and not the
assertion mechanism.

You create your own abstract TestCase class with your custom boolean-logic
methods.

public abstract class MyTestCase extends TestCase {
public static boolean containsText(final String string, final String
pattern) {
return string.indexOf(pattern) >= 0;
}
...
}

...

public class SomeTest extends MyTestCase {
public void testSomething() {
assertTrue(containsText("Hello", "el"));
}
}

...

Of course, after enough of this, your code starts to look like procedural
programming code, because what you REALLY want is to extend String, which you
can't do. If you really want to, you can wrap String and provide the extra
methods.

public class MyString {
private final String string;

public MyString(final String aString) {
string = aString;
}

public boolean contains(final String pattern) {
return string.indexOf(pattern) >= 0;
}

public boolean matchesRegex(final String regex) {
// ORO magic...
}
}

It's cleaner in one respect and uglier in another.
